messageBody:
On 30/11/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> Not quite, because "10 FAILURES" might mean that there are really ten broken
> tests, or that there is one broken and nine that failed because that first
> one failed. Or the break down could be 2/8. Or 3/7. Or... you get the
> idea.

Yes, indeed. But reading 1 FAILURE, 9 SKIPS, or 2 FAILURES, 8 SKIPS,
or 3 FAILURES, 7 SKIPS, doesn't tell me that the failures would have
worked if the broken ones had passed. I need to fix the (first) broken
test, then re-run the others. Which is what I do with JUnit now. So
how does knowing that 9 were skipped change my life?

Not to mention that with 3 FAILURES, 7 SKIPS, you don't _know_ that
the three failures weren't related, and should have been marked with a
dependency anyway.

> And it's so easy for the testing framework to provide accurate reports if it
> gets a little help from the developer...

Yes, but that help:
1) Requires work from the developer
2) Doesn't actually make the developer's life easier (the way the
tests get fixed and verified doesn't change)
3) Does make the tests run faster - but that's a seperate problem.

Both TestNG and JUnit provide accurate reports, with different
precision. TestNG trades off precision with uncertainty to get greater
speed - this is valid, but there are other ways to get the speed as
well.
